pages.text: Mudis have three genes that determine how they look. These are the B Locus, W Locus, and merle gene. The B Locus determines whether the dog has black or brown fur, while the W Locus determines whether they show the previously mentioned color or are white. The merle gene determines if they show merle patterning or not.

The B Locus has two potential alleles, the dominant 'B' and the recessive 'b'. The 'B' allele creates black fur, while the 'b' allele creates brown fur. Dogs with one copy of 'b' will carry the brown trait and may pass it on to pups, providing the potential for brown pups depending on the other parent. Dogs with two copies of 'b' will always create either brown carriers or brown puppies.
pages.title: B Locus

pages.text: The W Locus has two potential alleles, the dominant 'W' and recessive 'w'. The 'W' allele does not affect the coat's color, while the 'w' allele creates white fur. Dogs with one copy of 'w' will carry the white trait and may pass it on to pups, providing the potential for white pups depending on the other parent. Dogs with two copies of 'b' will always create either white carriers or white puppies.
pages.title: W Locus

pages.text: Understanding of merle is limited, but from our understanding dogs will either be merle or they won't. Dogs that have the merle trait have a distinctive patchy look. Two merle parents will always produce a merle pup, while merle bred to a non-merle can produce a pup with or without the merle trait.
pages.title: Merle
